metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (eddy covariance system of Zhangye wetland station, 2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Zhangye wetland station eddy covariance system (EC) in the midstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2020. The site (100.44640° E, 38.97514° N) was located in the Zhangye City in Gansu Province. The elevation is 1460 m. The EC was installed at a height of 5.2 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (Gill&Li7500A) was 0.25 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance system' entail in the context of data collection for hydrometeorological studies?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system in the context of data collection for hydrometeorological studies involves the acquisition of half-hourly turbulent flux data, including energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, using instruments such as an eddy covariance system and scintillometer.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'quality control procedure' in the context of processing hydrometeorological datasets?
Definition.Answer: In the context of processing hydrometeorological datasets, a 'quality control procedure' refers to the steps involved in data collection, processing, and archiving to ensure the data is accurate and reliable. It includes specific processes such as data filtering, correction, and assessment of data quality using criteria like atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity features.

Definition.Question: What defines an 'oasis–desert system' in terms of ecological and environmental research?
Definition.Answer: An 'oasis–desert system' in terms of ecological and environmental research is defined as a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is crucial for maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity. It serves as the core of regions' ecological environment and is foundational to their economic development, particularly in arid regions like western China.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers improve the interpretation of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers allows for detailed acquisition of half-hourly turbulent flux data, which can enhance the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems. This comprehensive data collection method provides insights into the interactions within these ecosystems, which are crucial for maintaining ecological stability and understanding the impacts of climate change.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges in data collection and processing might arise from the complex environmental conditions in oasis–desert areas, and how can they be addressed to ensure data quality and reliability?
Interpretation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face challenges such as ecological degradation and frequent dust storms, which can complicate data collection. Addressing these challenges involves implementing robust data processing and quality control procedures, such as filtering erroneous data and correcting for environmental factors like precipitation, to maintain the reliability of the datasets.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can long-term datasets from multiple meteorological stations contribute to a better understanding of the oasis–desert interactions and support sustainable development in these regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Long-term datasets from multiple meteorological stations provide a comprehensive view of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, as well as hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters. Such datasets are critical for recognizing oasis–desert interactions, supporting ecological security, and guiding sustainable development strategies by providing insights into the dynamics of these ecosystems over time.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the need for specific data processing steps like coordinate rotation and frequency response correction in eddy covariance systems for wetland observations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Data processing steps such as coordinate rotation and frequency response correction are necessary to ensure accurate and consistent measurements of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. These steps address issues related to instrument setup, such as the orientation of sensors and potential frequency distortions, thereby facilitating reliable data collection and analysis.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it critical to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems when collecting long-term data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems is essential to support the ecological security and sustainable development of oases. It ensures that the interactions between these systems are accurately captured, which is crucial for understanding their role in carbon cycling and achieving goals like carbon peaking and neutrality.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of implementing rigorous data quality control procedures on the reliability of hydrometeorological datasets in arid and semiarid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing rigorous data quality control procedures can significantly enhance the reliability of hydrometeorological datasets. By filtering out erroneous data, correcting for time lags, and performing frequency response corrections, the datasets become more accurate and dependable, which is crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid and semiarid environments. This process ensures that the data can be used effectively to support ecological stability and sustainable development in these regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the integration of auxiliary data, such as vegetation and soil parameters, influence the interpretation of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating auxiliary data like vegetation and soil parameters can provide a comprehensive understanding of the factors influencing energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. This additional context can enable researchers to identify interactions between biotic and abiotic components, offering insights into the underlying processes that drive these exchanges in oasis-desert ecosystems. Consequently, it supports the development of more robust models and strategies for maintaining ecological balance and promoting sustainable development.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes might arise from the establishment of long-term observational datasets in understanding the interactions between oasis and desert systems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The establishment of long-term observational datasets can lead to a deeper understanding of the interactions between oasis and desert systems. Such datasets provide valuable insights into the temporal dynamics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, which are crucial for recognizing patterns and trends over time. This knowledge can inform strategies to maintain ecological balance, support sustainable development, and address challenges like desertification and the degradation of natural resources in these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of collecting long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is crucial to achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in these areas. It also supports the ecological security and sustainable development of oases by recognizing oasis–desert interactions and maintaining ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers in the collection of energy and carbon flux data in arid and semiarid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers is significant as they provide half-hourly turbulent flux data, which is crucial for capturing the dynamics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. These instruments enable detailed monitoring and analysis of the interactions between the oasis and desert systems, contributing to a better understanding of the ecological and climatic processes in these regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the specific procedures and steps involved in processing eddy covariance data to obtain reliable flux measurements in arid and semiarid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures for processing eddy covariance data include using Eddypro software to handle the raw 10Hz data. Key steps involve outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation (double rotation), frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Additionally, quality evaluation of flux values is performed based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity tests. Data is further filtered to exclude data with instrument errors, data affected by precipitation, and data with significant gaps in the 10Hz raw data.

Enablement.Question: What data processing and quality control techniques enable the accurate assessment of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in desert-oasis systems?
Enablement.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedure involve data collection, processing, and archiving. Techniques such as the use of Eddypro software for processing 10Hz raw data into 30-minute intervals, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction are employed. Quality evaluation includes checks on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics.

Enablement.Question: How do technological advancements in meteorological instrumentation enable comprehensive data collection in arid and semi-arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements such as the use of eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations facilitate the comprehensive collection of turbulent flux data and hydrometeorological data. These instruments are capable of measuring parameters like radiation, soil heat flux, air temperature, and water vapor concentrations with high temporal resolution.

Enablement.Answer: Long-term observational datasets provide critical insights into the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes that occur in oasis-desert systems. By collecting data over extended periods, researchers can better understand the interactions and dynamics that contribute to the ecological stability and socio-economic development of oases.
